text.p: Following are some of the major events to have occurred on February 22 in history.
1370 - Robert II succeeded his uncle, David II, as King of Scotland, inaugurating the Stuart dynasty.
1512 - Amerigo Vespucci, Italian explorer of the New World, died. German cartographer Martin Waldseemuller suggested giving his name to the American continents.

1732 - George Washington, U.S. soldier and statesman, born. He defeated the British commander Cornwallis at Yorktown in 1781, sealing victory in the War of Independence. He became first president of the United States in 1789.
1784 - The Empress of China, first trading ship sent to China from the United States, set sail from New York on this day, arriving in China on August 28.
1787 - In France, the Assembly of Notables met for the first time.
1788 - Artur Schopenhauer, German philosopher, born. His best known work was "The World as Will and Idea" written in 1819. He greatly influenced both Nietzsche and Freud.
1819 - United States acquired Florida from Spain under the terms of an accord signed by Secretary of State John Quincy Adams and Spanish minister Don Luis de Onis.
1847 - In the American-Mexican War, U.S. forces under General Zachary Taylor defeated the Mexicans at the battle of Buena Vista.
1857 - Lord (Robert) Baden-Powell, British army officer and founder of the Boy Scout movement, born. He won fame during the Boer War as the defender of Mafeking.
1862 - Jefferson Davis inaugurated as president of the Confederate States of America.
1879 - Frank Winfield Woolworth opened his first "Great Five Cent Store" store in Utica, New York.
1886 - The Times became the first British newspaper to institute a personal column on its classified page.

1900 - Luis Bunuel, Spanish surrealist filmmaker, born. "Un Chien Andalou" and "L'Age d'or", collaborations with Salvador Dali, established Bunuel's reputation. A later success was his "Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie".
1913 - Francisco Madero, revolutionary president of Mexico, was assassinated by the military, along with vice-president Pino Suarez.

1932 - Edward Kennedy, U.S. senator and youngest brother of President John Kennedy, born. His political career never recovered from his involvement in a 1969 car accident at Chappaquidick in which Mary Jo Kopechne drowned.
1966 - Ugandan Prime Minister Milton Obote took full powers and had five ministers arrested.
1967 - U.S. and South Vietnames forces launched Operation Junction City, the biggest combined operation of the Vietnam War, attacking communist forces in Tayninh Province north of Saigon.
1967 - Indonesia's President Achmad Sukarno surrendered all power to premier General Suharto, remaining president in name only.
1979 - The Caribbean island of St Lucia gained full independence from Britain after 165 years. It became the 40th member state of the British Commonwealth.
1980 - The Israeli government introduced a new currency, the shekel, which replaced the Israeli pound.
1987 - Andy Warhol, U.S. pop artist, died. "Pop Art", recreations of everyday objects, found its most famous expression in Warhol's Campbell soup-can label reproduction.
1991 - In the Gulf War, the United States gave Iraq 24 hours to quit Kuwait or face an all-out ground war.

1994 - Aldrich Ames, a highly experienced CIA officer, and his wife were charged with being "moles". The couple received $1.5 million over a 10-year period in exchange for passing secrets to the Russians.

1994 - Scientists from Canada reported finding evidence of cigarette smoke in foetal hair, the first biochemical proof that the offspring of non-smoking mothers can be affected by passive cigarette smoke.
1996 - France became the first European Union country to restore diplomatic ties with rump Yugoslavia to the level of ambassadors.

1996 - A court found Cambodian Prince Norodom Sirivudh, King Norodom Sihanouk's exiled half-brother, guilty of criminal conspiracy and illegal weapons possession and sentenced him in his absence to 10 years in jail.
